altText: Group of people around a Russian cross in tall grass
caption: In September 2009, Nick Lekanoff, Sr., former Makushin resident, traveled with his daughter and other descendants of Makushin on the Tiglax to visit the village site, which had been left behind in the evacuation of 1942 and never permanently resettled.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: A homeland changed

altText: Twelve men and a dog pose for a photo
caption: After his aerological crew was captured by the Japanese in June, 1942, Senior Petty Officer William House survived 50 days in the hills of Kiska.  He ate grass, shellfish, and worms. Weighing 80lbs he surrendered and was respected for his perseverance.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: William C. House and the Aerological Detail on Kiska

altText: People crowd at the railing of a ship
caption: Pribilof villagers, here lining the railing of the USAT Delarof on the day of their departure (June 15, 1942), were evacuated with only a few hours notice and no idea of their ultimate destination.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: Evacuation and internment

altText: Four men gather around a invalid man
caption: Soldiers rub the frostbitten feet of a disabled soldier. Over 2000 weather-related casualties—the majority Attu feet—were recorded for U.S. troops. This number represents the largest classification of casualties suffered by American forces on the island.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: Challenging weather conditions

altText: Six men with guns carry a person on a stretcher in a valley.
caption: U.S. wounded are gathered from the battlefield on Attu Island.  The battle on Attu, lasting nearly 20 days, was the second most deadly in the Pacific Theater.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: The battle for Attu Island

altText: A uniformed man holds up a broken Russian cross
caption: The Aleutian campaign brought together Russian, Native Alaskan, Japanese, and Euroamerican cultures. During the war 7 historic churches were damaged or destroyed. Villages were unrecognizable or burned to the ground and personal belonging lost or stolen.
park: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
title: Cultural collision

title: Loggerhead Key

altText: tan-colored pueblo Indian ruins with blue sky and three people
caption: The Tiwa pueblo of Kuaua lies in ruin at Coronado Historic Site. The site includes a rebuilt kiva that displays reproductions of original murals adorning its walls. Be sure to go to the visitor center where some of the original murals are displayed.
park: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
title: Kuaua Ruin in Coronado Historic Site, Bernalillo, New Mexico

altText: adobe buildings including two beehive-looking ovens with people in a courtyard
caption: El Rancho de las Golondrinas was a historic paraje (stopping place) along El Camino Real. “The ranch of the swallows” dates from the early 1700s, and is now being used as a living history museum.
park: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
title: El Rancho de las Golondrinas, La Cienega, New Mexico

altText: shrubby desert scene with people walking under a cloud-filled sky
caption: Walk in the footsteps of settlers from the 1600s who had to walk along this dreaded yet unavoidable section of El Camino Real: Jornada del Muerto or Dead Man’s Journey.
park: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
title: Jornada del Muerto, County Roads A013 & E070, Sierra & Doña Ana Counties, New Mexico

altText: fort ruins in the sunlight with cottonwood trees on the left
caption: Fort Selden was built near the town of Las Cruces in 1865 and housed troops for 25 years. The visitor center offers exhibits on frontier military life during the fort’s heyday and the grounds are self-guided.
park: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
title: Fort Selden Historic Site, Radium Springs, New Mexico

altText: large white chapel under blue sky
caption: Spanish troops built a presidio (fort) and chapel at this site during the 1780s to protect settlements in the lower Río Grande Valley downstream from El Paso, Texas.
park: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario, Mission Trail, El Paso, Texas

altText: Mexican mission stands in the dirt
caption: Construction of the mission church began in 1760 but was never completed. The outstanding ruins are virtually the only visible remains of the complex of missions established in the area. The purpose was to convert Coahuiltecan Indians to Catholicism.
park: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
title: Mission San Bernardo ruins, Guerrero, Coahuila, Mexico

altText: lots of greenery along a river; sunflowers in the foreground
caption: Around 1746, explorer Jacinto de León discovered a ford that allowed safe passage across the Río Grande in this vicinity; it had probably been used for centuries by American Indians.
park: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
title: El Paso de Jacinto/Paso de los Indios, Webb County, Texas

altText: stone house ruins; briliant green grasses and trees on the right
caption: This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. Post-1750s.
park: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
title: Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas

altText: rock indentations in a dry creek with five people walking under clouds

park: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
title: McKinney Falls State Park, Travis County, Texas

altText: trail segment indentation with leaves in it, trees along the side

park: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
title: Mission Tejas State Park, Houston County, Texas

altText: Beaux-Arts brick and limestone building with large arched windows and cupola-topped towers.

title: Ellis Island Museum of Immigration

altText: Great Hall has terra cotta-colored tile floor, a balcony, large arched windows, and vaulted ceiling
caption: The Registry Room, also known as the Great Hall, is where millions of immigrants were inspected. They were required to pass both a medical and legal inspection before being allowed to enter the United States.
park: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
title: Ellis Island's Registry Room

altText: Brick and limestone building with maroon canopy leading to entrance.

altText: Honey oak colored tall desk on tiled floor in Great Hall with arched windows and vaulted ceiling.
caption: Inspectors at Ellis Island would conduct the legal examination from behind desks like these a century ago.

title: Replica Inspection Desk in the Registry Room

altText: Artificially-expanded largely rectangular island with straight seawalls and large buildings.

park: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument

altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church steeple during a sunset in Philadelphia.
caption: The church building at Gloria Dei 'Old Swedes' has been in use since 1700, making it the oldest church building in Pennsylvania and the second oldest in the United States.  The steeple was completed in 1703.
park: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
title: Steeple of the Gloira Dei Church

altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church yard showing tombstones with the church in the background.
caption: Gloria Dei Church was designated as a National Historical Site in 1942. The Gloria Dei congregation owns and maintains the church and the related buildings, its ministry and the grounds.
park: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
title: Gloria Dei Chuch yard

altText: A color photo of the interior of Gloria Dei Church showing the pulpit and a stained glass window.
caption: Situated above the pulpit is the only stained glass window in the church building.  Created in the mid 1800s, the window is the earliest example of American stained glass among the 3600 windows in the Philadelphia region.
park: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
title: Interior of the Gloria Dei Church

altText: A color photo of a model tall ship hanging inside Gloria Die Church.
caption: Hanging from the ceiling of Gloria Dei are models of the two ships that brought the first Swedish colonists to North America in 1638, the "Kalmar Nyckel" and the "Fogel Gryp."
park: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
title: Model of a ship hanging inside Gloria Dei Church

altText: A 19th century photograph of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground.

altText: Artists' Illustaration of Hopewell Furnace in operation circa 1840.
caption: Overview of the Hopewell Furnace "iron plantation" community in operation during its prime.
title: Historical Rendering of Hopewell Furnace in Operation, 1840

altText: Front of Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House
caption: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House housed single men or those living away from their families, who came to work at the furnace.
title: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House

altText: Side view of blacksmith shop with cast house behind it.
caption: The Cast House was the industrial center of the ironworks.  It is were iron ore was smelted into iron metal and products.  The smaller blacksmith shop formed iron metal into all kinds of necessary tools and goods used in everyday life.
title: Blacksmith Shop & Cast House

altText: Side view of Hopewell Stove in front of wagon running gear.
caption: The most notable manufactured product Hopewell Furnace made was its stoves.  They were produced by the thousands at Hopewell and other like furnaces in the early 19th century and were transported for sale by horse and wagon.
title: Hopewell Stove

altText: Demonstration charcoal pile smoldering.
caption: Charcoal was the fuel used to fire Hopewell Furnace and other furnaces of its age.  Thousands of bushles of charcoal were made from hardwood trees on the furnace lands and entered into the furnace to keep it "in blast."
title: Charcoal Pile

altText: Front porch of Garfield home showing red front door
caption: The front porch of James Garfield's home was the scene of the first front porch campaign. The presidential candidate gave patriotic speeches and met with thousands of people who came to which him well during the summer and fall of 1880.
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: The Front Porch, Garfield Home

altText: Visitor Center from the south
caption: The Visitor Center occupies the original carriage house, built in 1894.
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: Visitor Center

altText: Visitor Center main entrance off the parking lot.
caption: A friendly greeting awaits visitors who enter the Visitor Center. This historic building, constructed in 1894, serves as bookstore, exhibit gallery and auditorium where the park film is shown. Tickets for tours of the Garfield home are also available her
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: Visitor Center, Main Entrance

altText: a large gray house with a red roof
caption: Thousands to visitors came to this front porch to hear presidential candidate James A. Garfield speak in 1880.
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: James A. Garfield National Historic Site

altText: A view of the memorial library addition through the trees.
caption: Mrs. Garfield constructed a beautiful addition to the Garfield home following the President's assassination in 1881. These 9 rooms contain the first Presidential Memorial Library,  including the a fireproof vault which once contained Garfield's papers.
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: Library addition, north side

altText: Hand-painted tile shows a bird next with blue eggs
caption: Mrs. Garfield was known for her artistic talent, which softly blankets the interior of the Garfield home. In particular, the dining room boasts two tiles which were hand-painted by Mrs. Garfield, surround by others done by her children.
park: James A Garfield National Historic Site
title: Hand-painted Fireplace Tile, Garfield Dining Room

altText: An oak tree arches over a cannon-guarded rampart with historic house and American flag in background

title: French Quarter Visitor Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

altText: Model of an early Acadian home sits in a glass case

park: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
title: Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

altText: Exhibit case full of musical instruments
caption: Acadian (Cajun) music began in cabins and dancehalls and has become famous worldwide.
park: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

altText: A small red squirrel stands on a dead pine branch.

altText: Snow covers the ground and flocks pine trees.

altText: View of Kalaupapa Peninsula from Overlook
caption: The Kalaupapa peninsula was once a prison for those inflicted with Hansen's disease.  Approximately 8000 people were forced to live their lives in isolation here.
title: Overview of Kalaupapa Peninsula

altText: View of pali (sea cliffs) on the north shore of Molokai
caption: Kalaupapa National Historical Park contains some of the world's tallest sea cliffs, which formed a natural barrier to the Hansen's disease settlement.
title: Pali (Sea cliffs) at Kalaupapa

altText: View of residences along Damien Road
caption: Patients lived in a combination of group homes and single family residences at Kalaupapa.
title: Kalaupapa Settlement

altText: View of the sunrise over the north shore of Molokai
caption: Kalawao with its rocky shoreline was the landing spot for the first Hansen's disease patients sent to Kalaupapa.
title: Kalawao at Sunrise

altText: View of Black Sand Beach and Awahua Bay
caption: Black Sand Beach is one of several sandy beaches at Kalaupapa, most known for its sea turtle nesting habitat.
title: Black Sand Beach

altText: View of rock walls and native Hawaiian archeological sites at Kalaupapa.
caption: Kalaupapa is also home to one of the most well-preserved archeological complexes in all of Hawaii.
title: Archeological Sites at Kalaupapa

altText: Siloama Church at Kalawao settlement
caption: Siloama Church was the first church established at Kalawao in 1866.  It is one of two remaining buildings at Kalawao today.
title: Siloama Church at Kalawao

altText: View of St. Damien's Grave at Kalawao with ocean in background.
caption: Saint Damien is one of two Catholic saints at Kalaupapa who came to serve the Hansen's disease patients in the late 19th century.
title: St. Damien's Grave

altText: View of Paschoal Hall also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall
caption: Paschoal Hall, also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall, served as the community's recreational center with movies, entertainers, and dances.
title: Paschoal Hall

altText: View of grave markers at Papaloa Cemetery in Kalaupapa

title: Papaloa Cemetery

altText: View of Kana'ana Hou Church through gates

title: Kana'ana Hou Church

altText: View of warehouse and store at the Kalaupapa Pier
caption: The Kalaupapa Pier, warehouse, and store were the lifeline of the settlement during the 20th century. Historically, shipments of goods and supplies were sent to Kalaupapa weekly.
title: Kalaupapa Pier

altText: The Main Arsenal
caption: The Main Arsenal at Springfield Armory National Historic Site was first built in 1850 and today houses the park's amazing collection of historic firearms.
title: Springfield Armory National Historic Site

altText: Three Park Volunteers, holding historic firearms, on the grounds of the Armory against a cloudy sky.

title: Blank Firing Demostration

altText: The tower of the Armory with the flag at full mast blowing in the wind on a cloudy day.
caption: Following the closure of the Springfield Armory in 1968, public action would drive Congress to create Springfield Armory National Historic Site in the late 1970s.

altText: A double musket rack holding 645 Springfield US Model 1861 rifle muskets.
caption: Named after a poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, the Organ of Muskets consists of 647 Model 1861 Rifle Muskets. This structure would have held 1100 muskets when fully stocked and would have been one of many that filled the Arsenal during the Civil War.
title: Organ of Muskets

altText: The Springfield Armory Main Arsenal on a fall day, with blue skies and the flag at half staff.
caption: Springfield Armory began the production of small arms in 1794 and continued until its close in 1968. In 1978, the Armory reopened under the direction of the National Park Service as a National Historic Site.
title: Springfield Main Arsenal on a Fall Day

altText: The sun rises behind a green field with a cannon in the foreground.

altText: Two cannons sit in an icy field.

altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.
park: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia

altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.
park: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee

altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.
park: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky

altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.
park: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas

altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.
park: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
